newsitem.title: JAPAN: TOCOM precious metals end firmer as yen dips.
newsitem.headline: TOCOM precious metals end firmer as yen dips.

text.p: Yen-based Tokyo precious metals futures ended higher on Monday, reflecting the yen's weakness against the dollar and firmer bullion prices, traders said.
Gold prices ranged from 14 yen to 17 yen per gram firmer, with most-active benchmark April ending up 16 yen at 1,387 yen.
Platinum futures ranged from eight yen to 18 yen per gram higher. Benchmark April finished up nine yen at 1,478 yen.

Activity was lacklustre ahead of a Japanese market holiday on Tuesday. "Market players were tending to close positions before the holiday, as uncertainty over currency direction after G7 meeting limited fresh transactions," one trader said.
Spot gold was quoted at $341.60/90 per ounce at 0736 GMT, against $341.90/342.40 in New York on Friday.
A protracted delay in Russian exports of platinum group metals (PGM) to Japan lifted platinum group metals, especially palladium, the traders said.

"Private investors are waiting for a chance to cover their massive short positions in palladium futures. But it is unlikely palladium prices will fall sharply unless the PGM situation with Russia resolves itself," one trader said.
Palladium short-term lease rates -- the cost of borrowing the metal -- jumped to about 20 percent.

Platinum short-term lease rates remained high at around 12 percent. "High lease rates of platinum group metals made traders wary of building fresh shorts in the spot market, and activity was mainly dominated by inter-month trade at TOCOM," one trader said. Palladium futures ranged from four yen to 22 yen per gram higher. Benchmark April was up six yen at 603 yen.
Platinum futures ranged from eight yen to 18 yen per gram higher. Benchmark April was up nine yen at 1,478 yen.
Benchmark April silver was up 2.1 yen per 10 grams at 195.2 yen. The TOCOM precious metals market will be closed on Tuesday on a national holiday. Trading will resume on Wednesday.
